data.text:
Now this is an awesome Catholic witness! üôå

ESPN interviewed former Los Angeles Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers about his regular use of the latin term ‚ÄúNunc Coepi,‚Äù which means ‚ÄúNow I begin.‚Äù

Rivers, who is also a devout Catholic, husband, and father of seven children, explains that ‚Äúa priest friend of ours gave me that phrase years ago‚Ä¶it‚Äôs that never-ending begin.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou always hear ‚Äòlet‚Äôs go!‚Äô It‚Äôs another way that triggers ‚Äòbegin again.'‚Äù

‚ÄúAs a quarterback, it‚Äôs play-to-play. You‚Äôre always starting again, whether it‚Äôs good or bad..if you ask any of my children at home, ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs dad‚Äôs favorite phrase?‚Äù They would be right on it.‚Äù

Watch the full video from ESPN below:

The Latin phrase that helped Rivers begin again

Chargers QB Philip Rivers explains the Latin phrase ‚ÄúNunc Coepi,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúnow I begin,‚Äù and the role it plays in his life.

If you cannot see the video, please click here.

He also discussed the motto in a commencement speech at the Catholic University of America in 2014.

Check out his speech below:

As the Venerable Bruno Lanteri said, ‚ÄúIf I should fall even a thousand times a day, a thousand times a day I will, with peace in my heart, turn to God, ask his forgiveness, and begin again.‚Äù

What do you think of this Latin term? Will you apply it to your life?

[See also: Can We Please Pursue Spiritual Excellence At Least as Hard as We Do for Sports and Academics?]
